LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY
Borrower People's Republic of China (PRC)
Project Description The Yellow River is the second largest river in the PRC. Its
basin spans 800,000 square kilometers (km2) and is home
to 107 million people. The Yellow River Basin is frequently
affected by floods resulting in devastating economic and
social losses. The Project will reduce flooding incidence in
the  most  flood-prone  part  in  the  lower  reaches  of  the
basin.  This  will  be  achieved  by  a  combination  of
nonstructural  and  structural  measures  including  (i)
strengthening the capacity of the Government agencies
concerned  for  adopting  an  integrated  approach  to  the
management  of  the  Yellow  River  basin,  (ii)  introducing
state-of-the-art  river  embankments  and  reservoir  flood
control  systems  technology,  (iii)  reforestation  along  the
river embankments, and (iv) raising the village platform
above flood levels at the most vulnerable sites.

Rationale Frequent flooding is a major constraint to socioeconomic
development  in  the  Yellow  River  basin,  particularly  the
lower  reaches.  Past  measures  to  contain  floods,  which
emphasized structural approaches, had limited success.
International  experience  suggests  that  floods  are  most
effectively addressed through an optimal combination of
structural  and  nonstructural  measures,  following  an
approach to comprehensive basin management. This is in
line with Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) water policy
paper  and  the  technical  assistance  TA  2817-PRC:
Strategic  Options  for  Water  Resources  Management
approved in June 1997, which emphasized the need to
shift from flood control to flood management.
The emphasis on flood management by PRC authorities
has been heightened by the devastating floods in 1998,
which affected 7.33 million houses, caused 3,656 deaths,
affected 25 million hectares of farmlands, and resulted in
monetary losses estimated at Y248.4 billion ($30 billion
equivalent). The approach to flood management includes

limiting development in flood retention areas, conserving
natural lakes, strengthening vulnerable embankments, and
improving flood forecasting and early warning systems. A
Y27.6  billion  (about  $3.3  billion  equivalent)  flood
management plan incorporating those approaches for the
lower reaches of the Yellow River has been prepared by
the Government for implementation during 2001-2005. The
proposed Project forms part of the Government’s plan and
is aimed at preventing human catastrophes and economic
losses caused by floods in the basin. ADB has played an
important  role  in  promoting  the  comprehensive  basin
management  approach  adopted  in  the  plan,  and  its
continued involvement in implementing the plan will help
institutionalize  the  approach  in  the  management  of  the
Yellow River and other basins in the PRC.
Objective and Scope The objective of the Project is to reduce the incidence of
and damage from flooding in the lower Yellow River basin
through improved flood management. The Project scope
comprises  (i)  institutional  development  and  capacity
building  of  the  Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission
(YRCC), (ii) rehabilitating and upgrading existing structural
and  nonstructural  measures  for  flood  control,  (iii)
developing  flood  protection  measures  for  vulnerable
villages  at  selected  sites,  and  (iv)  supporting  project
management.

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Yellow River Flood Management (Sector)
Project.  The  Report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  the  Strategic
Planning  Study  for  the  Preparation  of  the  Yellow  River  Law,  and  if  the  proposed  loan  is
approved by the Board, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, shall
approve the TA.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. The Yellow River basin is PRC’s cradle of civilization because early dynasties emerged
from its middle basin along the Wei River valley near the present city of Xi’an. For centuries,
people who lived along the Yellow River had suffered from periodic floods. The last 3,500 years
saw 26 significant changes in the lower Yellow River’s course. The river settled into its present
channel in 1855. All major dynasties made tremendous efforts to control floods along the Yellow
River. However, constructing flood control facilities was formidable work because the river is
suspended at the lower reaches due to the heavy sediment load from upstream. Because
flooding and drought throughout history, and the consequent impact on poverty, in the Yellow
River basin have been frequent and serious, particularly in the lower reaches, the river became
known as the "sorrow of the PRC."
3. In August 1999, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved a TA to prepare a Yellow
River Flood Management Sector Project.1 The TA assisted the Ministry of Water Resources
(MWR) to prepare the feasibility study for a flood management project in the lower reaches of
the Yellow River. The consultant’s draft final report was submitted in September 2000. A Loan
Appraisal Mission2 was fielded in December 2000 to discuss the project, objective, scope, cost,
and project implementation arrangements. This report is based on the results of the TA reports,
Government  feasibility  studies,  findings  of  ADB  missions,  and  discussions  with  central,
provincial and local government officials, and beneficiaries. The linkages between the goals,
objectives, outputs, and inputs are shown in the project framework in Appendix 1.
III.  BACKGROUND
A.  Sector Description
1.  Floods
4. Population  and  economic  activity  in  the  PRC  have  increasingly  moved  onto  the
floodplains of major rivers. Despite massive investments in flood control and other works, flood
damage has increased with every major flood as evidenced during the floods of 1998. At the
same time, the combined demands for water for municipal supply, irrigation, industry, power,
and other uses exceed the available resources, and shortages of water for municipal supply and
irrigation are emerging as major problems, especially in northern PRC.

5. The PRC is afflicted with frequent floods. Its territory extends across upper, middle, and
lower latitudes, and owing to the influence of the monsoons, the country typically has humid
summers and dry winters. The rainfall on land averages 648 millimeters (mm) a year, which is
unevenly distributed over different regions and seasons. The average annual rainfall is over
1,600 mm in the southeast coastal region, gradually decreasing to less than 200 mm in the
northwest.  Generally,  over  half  of  the  yearly  precipitation  occurs  during  the  flood  season
between July and September. The concentration of rainfall in time and space causes disastrous
floods. The typhoons that occur over the northwestern Pacific also bring calamitous floods. Over
a  period  of  38  years  (1949-1987),  281  of  1,114  typhoons  that  occurred  over  the  ocean
(including the South China Sea) struck the PRC, bringing exceptionally heavy rains and causing
serious losses in the coastal areas.
6. Flooding  in  the  lower  Yellow  River  basin  has  created  widespread  hardship  for  all
residents  of  the  floodplains,  regardless  of  their  income  status.  Aside  from  direct  tangible
financial  losses,  floods  inflict  major  social  costs  due  to  deaths,  injuries,  displacement  of
households/communities, loss of personal belongings, and a general disruption to education,
livelihood, and family and social life. Relocating the flood victims to congested evacuation
camps exposes them to epidemics and social tension. Women, who form a significant but
underestimated percentage of the rural labor force, are typically burdened during flood events
by obligations to obtain drinking water, fuel, and food; to help maintain the health of family
members and livestock; and to protect household properties. Flood-affected families themselves
must contribute labor to relief and emergency works during the floods and to the cleanup and
recovery efforts after the floodwater recedes. In terms of livelihood, flooding in the river basin
causes subtler yet longer term losses to farm communities, as agricultural land suffers from a
decline in crop and tree yields due to waterlogging. In mitigating flood risks, the Project will
substantially lessen the likelihood of these social losses and stresses for the residents of the
floodplains.
7. Historical records show that between 206 BC and 1949 AD, more than 1,000 significant
flood disasters occurred in the PRC, averaging one every two years. Notable recent floods
include that of (i) the Huai River in 1931, inundating 4.27 million hectares (ha) of farmland and
causing  75,000  deaths;  (ii)  the  middle  and  lower  reaches  of  the  Yangtze  River  in  1931,
inundating more than 3.3 million ha of farmland, affecting 28.5 million people, and causing
145,000 deaths; and (iii) the Yellow River in 1933, affecting more than 3.6 million ha of farmland
and causing 18,000 deaths. From 1949 to 1988, the affected area averaged about 7.9 million ha
per year from large floods that occurred in 1954, 1956, 1963, 1964, and 1985. Although the
number of deaths has declined, the costs of damage have increased.
8. The most recent flood events occurred in 1996 and 1998. The 1996 flood affected some
5.12  million  houses,  caused  4,400  deaths,  impacted  31  million  ha  farmland,  resulted  in
monetary losses of Y220.8 billion ($26.7 billion), and reduced gross domestic product (GDP) by
about 4 percent. The estimates for 1998 were 7.33 million houses, 3,656 deaths, 25 million ha
farmland,  Y248.4  billion  ($30  billion),  and  3-4  percent  reduction  in  GDP.  These  are  only
estimates, but clearly the impacts have enormous implications for economic growth and human
welfare.
2.  Yellow River Basin
9. The Yellow River is the second largest river system in the PRC, covering nine provinces
and autonomous regions: Qinghai, Sichuan, Gansu, Ningxia, Inner Mongolia, Shaanxi, Shanxi,
Henan, and Shandong. The river rises in the northern foothills of the Bayankala Mountains on

3
the Qinghai Plateau at an elevation of 4,600 meters (m). The total drainage area is 795,000
square kilometers (km2) and has a population of 107 million.  The main river is 5,464 kilometers
(km) long (Map 1).
10. The basin is divided into three reaches, each with distinctive characteristics:
(i)  The upper reach on the Qinghai Plateau in the west of the basin at an elevation
of over 4,000 meters above sea level (masl) is the main source of runoff in the
basin; there are many hydropower schemes in this area.
(ii)  The middle reach joins the Hai River basin to the east with Mount Taihang as the
eastern boundary, at an elevation of 1,000-2,000 masl; the river flows through
narrow gorges, and the two largest dams, Sanmenxia and Xiaolangdi, are in the
downstream part of this area.
(iii)  The lower reach downstream to the coast has a general elevation of less than
100 masl, and is bounded by the hilly area of central Shandong at 400-1,000
masl; the river is suspended above the hinterland level throughout.  The estuary
area lies below 10 m, and the river discharges into the Bohai Sea.
11. Among the major river systems in the PRC, the Yellow River is the most complex in
hydrology,  hydraulics,  ecology,  and  human  intervention.  The  following  are  the  principal
characteristics of the basin:
(i)  Fragile  ecological  environment.  The  middle  reach  flows  through  the  world's
largest loess plateau, with an area of 640,000 km2. Most of the area is arid and
semiarid. Drought, wind-blown sand, and soil loss are severe.3
(ii)  Deficient in water and abundant in sediment. The annual average runoff for the
Yellow River is 58 billion cubic meters (m3), only one seventh that of the Mekong
River with a comparable catchment area. The annual average sediment load is
1.6 billion tons (t), making the Yellow River the most sediment-laden river in the
world.
(iii)  Suspended river. The lower Yellow River has formed a suspended river with the
riverbed generally 4-6 m higher than the adjacent ground. This is due to severe
soil loss in the middle reach and aggradation year by year within the confining
flood embankments. The potential damage to settlements and agricultural land in
the event of embankment failure is high, as the surrounding terrain is a flat plain.
(iv)  Radical  course  changes.  Avulsions4  have  taken  place  throughout  geological
times. In the past four millennia, the river has entered the Yellow Sea at points up
to 800 km away from the present river mouth. The last major avulsion took place
in the 1850s.
(v)  Wider  section  upstream  than  downstream,  with  a  correspondingly  higher
conveyance capacity upstream. For example, the river width is around 10 km in
Henan Province and 2-4 km in Shandong.

12. The lower reach of the Yellow River runs through two provinces, Henan (upstream) and
Shandong (coastal area) in the central part of the Northern Plain, before flowing into the Bohai
Sea.  The total population of the two provinces is about 183 million: 94 million in Henan, the
most populous among PRC’s provinces and autonomous regions, and 89 million in Shandong,
which is highly industrialized. The total product of primary industry accounts for only 16 percent
of the gross provincial product in Shandong, compared with about 25 percent in Henan. Henan
is a major producer of wheat, corn, and cotton, mostly grown with irrigation. More than 80
percent of the population in Henan lives in the rural area.
13. Henan is a relatively poor interior province. In 1999, its per capita annual rural income
was Y1,948 ($235), 88 percent of the national rural average of Y2,210 ($266). Shandong is
located in the developed coastal zone and average annual per capita income in its rural area
was Y2,550 ($307) in 1999, 31 percent higher than that in Henan. Among PRC’s 31 provinces
and autonomous regions, Henan ranked 19th in rural income, and Shandong 8th.
14. Of the 113 counties in the flood-prone areas, 43 in Henan and Shandong are especially
vulnerable to inundation since they are located along the Yellow River and its lower tributaries.
The counties at highest risk are densely populated, with 661 persons per km2 and a total
population of 32.8 million. The rural population in the flood-prone area is estimated at 28.8
million (87 percent of total), of which 10.7 million form part of the labor force. Available arable
land is limited at about 0.09 ha per person. The 43 counties include the inner floodplains (i.e.,
areas inside the main river embankments) that are home to 1.7 million residents living in 2,193
villages.
15. The river reach downstream of the Dongping flood retention basin, about 400 km from
the  estuary,  located  in  Shandong  has  a  smaller  cross  section  with  only  about  half  the
conveyance capacity of the channel upstream. This suggests that Dongping Lake has long been
a natural storage area for floods. The lake and an additional storage area to the south are
encircled with high embankments, providing an effective flood storage capacity. The basin can
be flooded from the Yellow River via inlet flood sluices; drainage is partly to the Yellow River,
and partly to the Huai River to the south, once the flood recedes. The Dongping flood retention
basin would be flooded in the event of a flood with a return period of around once in 25 years.
The storage capacity allows the river downstream to match the upstream reach.
16. The loess plateau in the upper and middle reaches of the Yellow River is the most
severely eroded area in the world.  The total eroded area is 454,000 km2: 337,000 km2 eroded
by water and 117,000 km2 by wind. The heavily water-eroded area with an erosion modulus
greater than 5,000 t per km2 per year covers 146,500 km2, nearly 40 percent of the total area of
that category in the PRC.  The 36,700 km2 of severely water-eroded area with an erosion
modulus greater than 15,000 t per km2 per year accounts for 90 percent of the total in this
category in the PRC. The high sediment load of the Yellow River originates mainly from the
highly erosive areas of the loess plateau, i.e., from Hekouzhen to Longmen and the middle and
upper reaches of the Jing, Luo, and Wei rivers.
17. Measures to control sediment involve major engineering works, most notably Xiaolangdi
reservoir (funded by the World Bank), which is designed to trap and contain riverborne sediment
for about 20 years in the dead storage of the reservoir.5 Long-term measures include terracing,
checkdams, reforestation, planting of grasses, and promotion of horticulture in the eroding

areas. The Government plans to rehabilitate 157,300 km² by 2010 (one third of the loess
plateau), and to completely rehabilitate all affected areas by 2050.
18. Building up farmland by terracing and utilizing land behind silt trap dams will increase
agricultural output and allow the restoration of forest and grass on formerly cultivated sloping
land. Vegetation cover may be improved or restored by introducing suitable species of trees,
grasses, and bushes in appropriate combinations.  The development of grass and forest areas
conserves soil and water, and promotes the development of animal husbandry, forestry, and
orchards. Conservation farming to retain moisture and soil includes fallow fields, limited tillage,
cultivating along contours, and contour furrow-and-ridge planting.
19. Water consumption in the Northern Plain has been increasing at the rate of 4.7 percent
annually. The average annual flow in the Yellow River is 58 billion m3. About 38 billion m3, or 65
percent, is diverted for irrigation; 6.4 billion m3, or 11 percent, is used by industries and cities
within the watershed; and 4.1 billion m3, or 7 percent, is diverted to cities outside the watershed
(e.g., Zhengzhou City). In 1970, the Yellow River ran dry in stretches along Shandong for 21
days. In 1996, the dry period was 133 days and in 1997, it was 226 days.6 Water shortages
have contributed to the disappearance of wetland habitats__especially in the lower reaches__and
aggravated  the  decline  of  aquatic  fauna  and  the  existing  water-quality  problems.  Water
shortages may lead to future social conflict, unrest, and food insecurity. The demand for water is
currently so high that farmers face strong competition for water from local cities and industries.
B.  Government Policies and Plans
1.  1988 Water Law
20. The Government has placed high priority on water resource management to minimize
the impacts of floods and droughts. The basic principles of water resource management are
stated in the current implementing guidelines for the Water Law and related laws, such as the
Law on Water and Soil Conservation, Water Pollution Control, Flood Control, and Environmental
Protection.
(i)  Water resources are owned by the State, to be developed and utilized at its
discretion. Control is to be exercised through a water rights system covering the
consumptive use of both groundwater and surface water.
(ii)  A system for the unified administration of basinwide water resources is to be
adopted  in  association  with  administration  at  various  levels  and  by  various
departments throughout the country. Provinces retain responsibility for systems
within their own territory.
(iii)  Water pollution control is to be an integral part of the development and utilization
of water resources.
(iv)  Service entities are to charge water fees on all consumptive uses of both surface
water and groundwater.
(v)  Allocation and consumption of water must be planned and economized through
technical and organizational measures, and reuse promoted.
21. The 1988 Water Law’s structure and level of detail show flexibility and allow adjustments
as conditions change and new management measures are devised. An extensive body of rules,

assessments and direct labor along reaches of the rivers.
23. To clarify the diverse responsibilities for water management, the Government is revising
the 1988 Water Law, which does not adequately address emerging issues. The revision will
stipulate that water resources are to be administered in a holistic, unified way, not by sector.
The proposed amended Water Law has been discussed by the National People’s Congress
(NPC) and is expected to be approved shortly. For effective and efficient water management,
implementable mechanisms for water pricing and cost recovery will be stipulated.
2.  1997 Flood Control Law
24. The Flood Control Law, which NPC passed on 29 August 1997, came into force on 1
January 1998. This is the first law for preventing and controlling natural disasters (although
there have been previous administrative regulations promulgated under the water and other
laws) and thus filled a gap in the water legislation system. This law is important because it
addresses the specific nature of causes and remedial measures to be taken to prevent and
control floods. It requires a unified and integrated planning approach with comprehensive river
basin plans prepared by the river basin commissions, and at administrative levels of local
government, specifically including urban areas. The law introduced the important mechanism of
designating "planned reserve zones/areas," where special rules may apply on water use and
activities. It further specifies requirements for operating reservoirs and other hydraulic works; for
multiple uses in river course realignments and lake embankments; and for preparing a flood
impact  assessment  for  projects  in  flood-prone  areas.    MWR  is  primarily  responsible  for
implementing this law.
3.  River Basin Commissions
25. As early as November 1949, the Government stated that use of water in any river must
be planned in a unified manner and managed in an integrated way so that water resources can
be  optimally  utilized.  The  principle  of  united  water  administration  relies  on  centralized
management  to  verify  water  rights  and  appraise,  decide,  and  initiate  water  conservation
undertakings with multiple objectives. During the 1950s, river basin plans were completed for all
seven major river basins. The importance of basin planning and management was confirmed by
the 1988 Water Law.
26. There are currently six commissions for interprovincial river basins (Songhua-Liao, Hai,
Yellow,  Huai,  Yangtze,  and  Pearl)  and  one  lake  commission  (Tai)  under  the  direct
administration of MWR, but established with the consent of the State Council. The functions of

7
the commissions are delegated to them by MWR. Many have been allocated responsibilities
that go beyond the particular river or lake basin concerned, so they essentially act as regional
offices of the ministry. The Yellow River Conservancy Commission (YRCC) is authorized to act
in some inland river basins (e.g., in Xinjiang) and the Tai Lake Commission was recently made
responsible for some rivers in Fujian Province. While the river basin commissions are primarily
responsible for the specific river or lake basins for which they are named and are widely seen to
be basin agencies, in practice they fall short of a true basin commission as they do not have the
requisite authority for implementing an integrated approach for water resource management.
4.  River Basin Plans
27. MWR is preparing a long-term Comprehensive River Basin Plan covering a period of 20-
30 years for each of the seven major river basins.7 MWR has also prepared flood control plans,
irrigation plans, water and ecology conservation plans, and water resources development plans
for each of the seven basins.
28. YRCC prepared an Outline Management Plan for the Yellow River Basin covering the
period 2000-2020. After review by MWR, YRCC submitted the plan to the State Development
Planning Commission (SDPC) in 1997. The objectives of the plan are to (i) reinforce the lower
Yellow River embankments to eliminate vulnerable locations, (ii) strengthen the riverbank and
train the bed to control the shifting of the main stream, (iii) slow down the extension of the
estuary into the sea, (iv) improve the safety of the Yellow River floodplain and reduce the losses
and impacts of floods, and (v) strengthen nonstructural measures for flood management.
29. MWR has prepared a medium-term plan for the Yellow River called a Program for 2010.
In addition, MWR prepared the Tenth Five-Year Plan (10th FYP) for the Yellow River (2001-
2005) and submitted it to SDPC. For the lower reach of the Yellow River, the total investment
under the 10th FYP is estimated at Y27.6 billion (about $3.3 billion). The proposed Project will
cover the implementation of the most urgent construction works of both structural measures and
nonstructural measures included in the 10th FYP for the Yellow River.
30. The major flood of 1998 in the Yangtze and Songhua rivers and drought in the Yellow
River  basin  catalyzed  public  awareness  on  the  severity  of  the  degradation  of  the  natural
vegetation and potential environmental and economic consequences. In response to the public
concern, the Government initiated a Natural Forest Protection Project to (i) terminate logging in
natural  forests  in  designated  provinces,  (ii)  convert  cultivated  sloping  land  to  forest  and
grassland, (iii) regenerate barren land, and (iv) restructure the forest industry and re-employ
forest workers and affected farmers. This project for the upper and middle Yellow River was
incorporated in the Great West Development Program in 2000.
31. The  PRC  adopted  a  number  of  measures  to  protect  and  improve  the  ecological
environment in the western region. Pilot programs were launched in 188 counties for restoring
forest  and  grassland  in  700,000  ha  of  cultivated  land  to  prevent  soil  erosion.  In  addition,
530,000 ha of mountainous areas were closed for afforestation. All sloping and ecologically
important farmland with serious water and soil erosion problems will be restored as forest or

vulnerable embankments.

2.  Cost Recovery Mechanisms
50. The PRC policy to levy a fee for the privilege of diverting water__surface water and
ground water__for consumptive and other specified uses is separate and in addition to the policy
to charge for all water-related services. The decision to levy the fee and its specific use is left to
the province and, where assessed, is usually collected by the county Department of Water
Resources (for rural users) and county Department of Construction (for urban users) to be
shared with governments at other levels. In many instances, several agencies seek to be
allowed to collect the fees. The Water Law states that the fee may be used only for improving
water management.
51. Water prices at present reflect mainly variable costs and fail to provide for recovery of
fixed investments. Starting with new projects, MWR has recommended raising water prices to
encourage efficiency. MWR anticipates the new pricing system will promote water conservation,
stimulate greater private sector participation in water supply, and reduce future water shortages.
Irrigation water, about 70 percent of total water use, faces a threefold price increase, while
urban and industrial water prices also will rise. Low prices stifle investment in water supply and
treatment facilities.
52. Over  the  last  decade,  the  Government  has  increased  the  budget  to  improve  and
strengthen the flood protection facilities in the major river basins, almost 15 times more in 1999
than in 1990. Investment for flood protection is expected to be further increased under the 10th
FYP.  Embankments  will  be  improved  and  strengthened  for  effective  flood  protection  and
minimal flood damage. At the same time, operation and maintenance (O&M) costs will be
increased to ensure the financial and physical sustainability of the embankments.
53. Because of budgetary constraints faced by central and local governments, growing fiscal
concerns,18 and the large increases in flood protection investments, the Government has seen
the need to recover costs, particularly for O&M, from beneficiaries in all major river basins,
including the Yellow River. In the other major basins__the Yangtze and Songhua__provincial
governments have been levying and collecting fees for O&M of the river infrastructure. The
Water  Law  (1988),  to  be  amended  shortly,  is  likely  to  stipulate  a  standard  cost-recovery

beneficiaries. Increased tariffs will provide market-based incentives to conserve and recycle
water and put a scarce resource to the most productive use.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
59. Frequent flooding causes poverty and human suffering and is a major constraint to
socioeconomic development in the Yellow River basin. The lower reaches of the Yellow River
are the worst affected. Although floods have been contained within certain limits, effective flood
management  and  soil  erosion  control  have  not  been  achieved.  Because  of  increasing
population and corresponding economic activities in flood-prone areas, the economic damage
caused  by  flooding  is  increasing.  There  is  a  need  to  shift  from  flood  control  to  flood
management through  an  integrated  land  and  water  resources  management  approach  that
includes soil conservation in the upper catchment, optimal water management throughout the
basin, flood control measures, and complementary flood forecasting and warning systems in the
lower reaches.
60. The embankments and river training works at several vulnerable points along the Yellow
River need major repair and maintenance. The embankments around flood retention basins
need strengthening to reduce the risk of failure. Establishing a morphological prediction system
along the lower reach including the estuary will allow sustainable flood management. To give a
higher  level  of  security  to  vulnerable  people,  old  infrastructure  (roads,  bridges,  platforms,
temporary shelters, etc.) must be upgraded and new ones constructed on the floodplain and in
retention basins.
61. The Government’s 10th FYP for the Yellow River and MWR’s Program for 2010 for the
Yellow River give the strategic direction in implementing flood management works in the basin
(para. 29). The Executing Agency, MWR, and the Implementing Agency, YRCC, are well-
established and experienced in the flood control sector and have the necessary capability to
implement the proposed Project. Many relatively small-scale subprojects are dispersed over 800
km and will be developed in stages. ADB’s sector loan modality is appropriate for a project that
comprises a few core subprojects and about 30 subprojects to be identified and appraised in the
course  of  implementation.  The  sector  loan  approach  will  provide  necessary  flexibility  in

preparing  and  implementing  subprojects  in  a  phased  manner,  consistent  with  the  local
implementation capacity.
B.  Objective and Scope
62. The Project aims to reduce the incidence and damage of flooding in the lower Yellow
River basin through improved flood management. The Project will also help to enhance the
environment and protect the poor and near-poor by strengthening/improving protection against
floods that could push them further into poverty through the loss of crops, incomes, and assets.
63. The project area23 is the lower reach of the Yellow River from downstream of Xiaolangdi
Dam to the Bohai Sea, a distance of some 800 km. It covers 3,956 km2 where 1.731 million
people  live  in  2,071  villages    (Map  2).    The  area  includes  the  inner  floodplain,  the  main
embankments and the adjacent land in the outer floodplain. This area, including parts of the Hai
and Huai river basins, is part of the 117,900 km2 in the Northern Plain vulnerable to flooding
from the Yellow River.
64. While preparing the 10th FYP for the Yellow River, YRCC also prepared prefeasibility
reports for subprojects in the project area. Considering these reports, ADB and YRCC agreed
on the priority of certain project components. As recommended in the study on strategic options
for  the  water  sector  (footnote  8),  the  importance  of  nonstructural  measures  for  flood
management was duly recognized. Source control and watershed management measures are
centered on holistic river basin management planning presenting an integrated approach, with
full attention to environmental issues. The following are the four project components: (i) flood
management measures, (ii) flood control works, (iii) village flood protection, and (iv) project
management.

(v)  physical and mathematical modeling and field testing of various flood protection
structures and river training works;

2.  Flood Control Works
66. Embankments of the lower reach are essential structures for containing the Yellow
River.  The river in flood is a dangerous water body 800 km long and up to 20 km wide, held
behind embankments up to 14 m above the surrounding land level. Only the embankments
prevent the floodwaters from inundating vast areas of valuable land.  The body of floodwater is
powerful and turbulent, and aggressively attacks the embankments in ways that are difficult to
predict. Major investments have been made in enclosing the area with a high flood embankment
and in flooding and drainage sluices. Many structural problems within the existing embankments
have accumulated over time: (i) non-homogeneous soil, (ii) joints between construction layers,
(iii) lack of proper compaction, (iv) historical breaches and avulsions leaving weak foundations,
(v) emergency repairs carried out with materials immediately available, and (vi) wild animal dens
and burrows.
67. Flood control works will involve (i) strengthening the existing embankment including
constructing cutoff walls24 in the embankment, (ii) river training, (iii) strengthening the role of
retention  reservoirs,  and  (iv)  planting  trees  along  the  embankment.  About  120  km  of
embankment will be strengthened, about 25 km of river training works will be implemented, and
six vulnerable spots of the embankment will be reconstructed. Considering the location, scale of
works, accessibility, and urgency, the embankment at Kaifeng and Dongping flood retention
basin  were  selected  as  two  core  subprojects  representative  of  subprojects  under  this
component (Appendix 3).

drainage system will be improved to minimize waterlogging in the area. Trees and grasses will
be planted to stabilize and protect the newly built platform slope.

V.  PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A.  Economic Evaluation
121. Economic analyses were carried out for the three core subprojects to evaluate the
returns on project investments to the economy (Appendix 12). The economic life of the project
structures is 40 years, including the construction period. A shadow exchange rate factor of 1.07
was applied to derive the economic cost and benefit streams. The economic wage rate of
unskilled labor is 90 percent of the financial wage rates. Estimated benefits from the subprojects
were  derived  based  on  avoidance  of  damage  to  existing  assets,  avoided  disruptions  to
agricultural and industrial production, and avoided emergency repairs of the flood embankment.
Key assets in the flood-prone areas include standing crops, public infrastructure, and buildings
(residential, commercial, and industrial). Potential disruption to economic activities is caused not
only by floodwater, but also by the deposition of silt on agricultural and urban areas, which
would reduce agricultural outputs for at least one year and entail substantial recovery costs.
122. To calculate the economic internal rates of return (EIRRs), core subproject benefits were
annualized by adjusting the total estimated flood damages by the probabilities of floods, under
the with-project and without-project scenarios. The magnitude of damage in different parts of the
flood-prone areas was adjusted according to the expected levels of inundation as simulated by
YRCC.  For  flood-prone  areas  with  lower  potential  economic  growth,  benefits  were  mostly
derived from the lower risk of damages. In areas with good potential for economic growth, such
as  Kaifeng  County,  benefits  were  largely  derived  from  enhanced  economic  growth  made
possible due to investment in the core subproject. Benefits from the platforms were calculated
as those of the embankments. However, potential losses due to flooding were limited to the
estimated loss of private and community properties on existing platforms because the platforms
do not protect assets outside the platforms.
123. The costs of subprojects include the costs of land acquired, resettlement, survey and
designs,  construction,  construction  supervision,  environment  mitigation  measures,  and
subproject management. The costs of land acquisition and temporary construction sites are
based on the forgone economic agricultural incomes, estimated at about Y8,925 per ha per
season. The estimated compensation costs for structures dismantled as part of the resettlement
activities were based on their reconstruction costs.
124. The estimated EIRRs are 14, 19, and 17 percent for the subprojects at Changyuan,
Kaifeng,  and  Dongping,  respectively.  Similar  EIRRs  are  expected  for  the  other  candidate

31
subprojects to be included in the Project. These estimates are robust, given the relatively limited
scope of benefits accounted for in the economic evaluation. The benefit estimates excluded the
avoidance of injuries, hospitalization, loss of lives, mobilization of flood-fighting crews, and
large-scale emergency evacuation that will occur during major floods. The economic evaluation
also excluded potential loss, such as loss due to disruption of communication and transportation
to areas adjacent to flood-prone zones, and loss of household assets, livestock, and farm
machinery.  The  EIRRs,  therefore,  provide  conservative  estimates  of  the  true  social  and
economic benefits of the Project.

revolutionary bases. Poor transport, environmental instability, slow economic growth, lack of

131. The project design takes into account potential technical and economic risks. The main
risks,  which  could  result  in  implementation  delays  and  cost  overruns,  are  associated  with
abnormal  rainfall  and  unexpected  floods  that  will  adversely  affect  the  construction  of
embankments and river training works during project implementation. To mitigate these risks,

expedite  subproject  selection  and  preparation  of  IEE/EIA  and  resettlement  plans.  These

DESCRIPTION OF CORE SUBPROJECTS
1. Under the flood control works component, two core subprojects, Kaifeng embankments
reinforcement and Dongping flood retention, were studied; and under the village flood protection
component, Changyuan platform was studied. The following paras. briefly describe the core
subprojects.
1.  Kaifeng Embankment Reinforcement
2. The project works entail strengthening over 8.4 kilometers (km) of the right embankment
of the Yellow River in the vicinity of Kaifeng City.  The works will improve embankment stability,
minimize seepage through the embankment at high water levels, and increase the time an
erosive attack from the river would take to breach the embankment. High rates of seepage and
the consequent erosion of the embankment material pose the greatest threat of a breach.
3. The present embankment was built up from the original natural levees by repeated
widening and raising through the years. The quality of construction works has varied according
to prevailing technical knowledge and sociopolitical conditions. Many structural problems have
accumulated within the embankment over time: (i) non-homogeneous soil, (ii) joints between
construction layers, (iii) lack of proper compaction, (iv) historical breaches and avulsions leaving
weak foundations, (v) emergency repairs carried out with materials immediately available, and
(vi) wild animal dens and burrows.
4. Construction of a new embankment on the inner floodplain some 100 meters (m) from
the existing main embankment is proposed.  The area between the new and old embankments
will be filled with warped material.  Originally, warping was carried out using a sand-water mix
dredged from the riverbed.  Recently, it was found that more suitable warping material is
obtained from borrow pits on the floodplain close to the river. Where the new embankment and
warped area would affect existing settlements, a cutoff wall will be constructed in the old main
embankment, leaving the settlements undisturbed. The total length of the new embankment is
around 7 km, and the cutoff wall, 1.4 km.
5. The warping material is loosened and made into a slurry by high pressure hoses.  The
slurry is pumped overland at distances up to 5 km to the area between the embankments,
where it is discharged into prepared lined basins and allowed to drain and consolidate naturally.
By greatly increasing the width of the embankment, even with poor construction material, the
stability of the outer slope is improved, seepage reduced, and the distance through which the
river would have to cut the embankment in the event of an erosive attack increased.
6. Where warping would entail significant relocation of villages at the inner foot of the
embankment, cutoff walls are proposed. The wall is constructed along the center line of the
embankment from the relatively impermeable subsurface to the embankment crest, creating a
near impermeable barrier within the embankment.  The wall may be a cement-soil mix in situ
piled wall, where the required depth is less than 16-18 m, or a diaphragm wall of nonreinforced
concrete 0.22 m wide for greater depths. This virtually eliminates seepage and the threat of
embankment failure from seepage erosion.  While the construction of the piled wall is relatively
straightforward, excavating the trench for the diaphragm wall will expose cracks and voids in the
embankment structure.  Where these are large, techniques to construct the diaphragm wall
have  to  be  perfected  by  the  Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission  (YRCC),  which  will
continuously study the most efficient and economical way of preventing floods.

2.  Dongping Flood Retention Basin
7. The  subproject  is  in  Dongping,  Liangshan,  and  Wengshan  counties  of  Shandong
Province, and lies southeast of Dongping Lake. The Dongping flood retention basin consists of
a  209-square  kilometer  (km2)  natural  lake  (Dongping)  surrounded  by  an  embankment.
Immediately adjacent is an artificial 418 km2 second basin (outer lake) that is also surrounded
by an embankment.1 The Dongping flood retention basin is a vital link in flood management for
the lower reaches of the Yellow River and its main function is to cut off the Yellow River’s peak
floods, and maintain the discharge in Aishan (just downstream of Dongping's outlet to the
Yellow River) at below 10,000 cubic meters per second (m³/s). This is achieved by diverting a
maximum of 8,500 m³/s into the flood storage area. This function is vital for safeguarding
strategic locations downstream, such as Jinan City (capital of Shandong Province), railway

upgrading  is  necessary  to  make  it  safe.  The  subproject  focuses  on  upgrading  the  outer
embankment along the artificial outer lake and removing unused old irrigation facilities. The
subproject’s main components consist of (i) constructing about 18 km of diaphragm walls; (ii)

material to strengthen the embankment and allow plants to grow; (iii) dismantling two disused
sluices; and (iv) upgrading 10 sections of auxiliary roads along a total length of about 900 m,
and constructing 19 flood observation houses with platforms.
8. Owing to wind-generated waves in the basin, stone armoring is required up to the
predicted wave height when the basin is filled.  Along the entire length, the armoring has to be

purpose reservoir design and are no longer in use.  The sluices lie on old river courses and
represent weak points in the embankment. They will be removed and the embankment rebuilt.

SECTOR LENDING ARRANGEMENTS FOR LAND ACQUISITION AND RESETTLEMENT
A. Introduction
1. In  accordance  with  ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement  policy,  resettlement  will  be
implemented through the resettlement policy framework (RPF) and resettlement procedural
guidelines (RPG). RPF and RPG stipulations apply to all subprojects that are prepared and
approved for inclusion in the sector loan. Three core subproject resettlement plans (RPs) have
already been prepared for the Kaifeng, Changyuan, and Dongping subprojects in accordance
with the RPF and RPG and these will form models for land acquisition and resettlement under
new subprojects.
B. Resettlement Policy Framework
2. The  RPF  reflects  both  borrower’s  regulations  and  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary
resettlement.  The  main  RPF  principles  follow:  (i)  minimize  negative  impacts  as  much  as
possible, (ii) carry out resettlement and compensation so as to improve or at least restore the
pre-project living standards of the affected people (AP), (iii) fully inform and consult closely with
APs on compensation options and RP design, (iv) provide asset compensation at replacement
rates, and (v) provide compensation for lost assets and resettlement subsidies in full prior to
ground leveling and demolition. Disbursement for each subproject will be conditional upon
ADB’s approval of the subproject RP.
3. The RPF stipulates eligibility and entitlement provisions for land losses, house losses,
crop losses, and loss of other assets. Land losses will be compensated as follows: (i) APs losing
agricultural and residential land will be compensated through land-for-land arrangements, or
land reallocation within village domains; (ii) if land-for-land arrangements are not feasible, the
AP losing agricultural land will be reclassified and provided with job opportunities; (iii) cash
compensation for lost land will be paid at the rates stipulated by the 1998 Land Law to the
villages  which,  in  turn,  will  use  the  funds  received  for  infrastructure  and  services  directly
benefiting the affected communities. Resettlement subsidies for land acquired will be directly
paid to the AP in cash through the village offices. Compensation for house losses will be paid
directly to the AP in cash at replacement cost free of demolition costs and salvaged materials.
Compensation for crop losses will be paid directly to the AP in cash at current market prices.
Vulnerable households will receive assistance for house relocation and reconstruction, to be
organized by the Village Committee.  The Environmental and Social Division (ESD) in the
Yellow  River  Conservancy  Commission  (YRCC)  will  pay  particular  attention  to  developing
effective income restoration strategies for APs below the poverty line.
C. Resettlement Procedural Guidelines
4. Appropriate RPs have been prepared for the three core subprojects. For subprojects yet
to be identified, specific RPGs have been established to guide RP preparation and to provide a
differentiated approach commensurate with the magnitude of the impact of each subproject.
5. The established RPGs require the following procedures: (i) after subproject identification
and completion of preliminary technical design, YRCC carries out an impact survey to determine
the magnitude of impacts; (ii) if, through this process, the subproject impacts are identified as

significant,1 YRCC will prepare a full RP; (iii) if the initial screening concludes that subproject
impacts are less than significant, YRCC will instead prepare a short RP. 2
D.   Institutional Responsibilities

Management  Bureau.  If  still  unresolved  within  two  weeks,  the  case  can  be  sent  to  the
correspondence departments of other government agencies or the resettlement office. Final
appeal is available in the civil courts as established by the Regulations for Administrative
Redress.

STRATEGIC PLANNING STUDY FOR THE PREPARATION
OF THE YELLOW RIVER LAW
A.  Objectives
1. The objectives of the technical assistance (TA) are to conduct strategic studies relating
to integrated water resources management of the Yellow River basin and to search for legal
countermeasures for outstanding problems in the Yellow River basin, to provide the National
People’s Congress (NPC) with data and recommendations in formulating the Yellow River Law.
B.  Scope
2. The TA will (i) review the baseline information and data on social, environmental,
economic, and technical conditions of the Yellow River basin; (ii) identify socioeconomic
development opportunities and assess problems and constraints, giving due attention to the
specific characteristics of the river and the diversified nature of the basin area; (iii) review
relevant Government policies and plans as well as the current institutional setup for water
resources management in general, and for the Yellow River in particular; (iv) prepare
comprehensive studies of the issues for effective water resources management and sustainable
socioeconomic development of the Yellow River basin; and (v) propose policy and legal
recommendations in formulating the Yellow River Law.
3. The study will cover seven themes: (i) water resources management: focusing on a
comprehensive management system and mechanism for allocating and saving water, identifying
the supply and demand relationships between sustainable use of water resources and
socioeconomic development; (ii) water resources protection: focusing on the study of the
responsibilities and regulations for protecting water resources and preventing pollution; (iii) flood
protection and river management: river dredging and river training, including structural and
nonstructural measures, and establishing effective flood control and disaster mitigation
mechanisms, risk management system, and policy; (iv) soil and water conservation: setting
rules and regulations for integrated planning and management emphasizing comprehensive
benefit evaluation through participatory approaches; (v) water pricing and cost recovery
mechanism: evaluating and exploring the most efficient and effective mechanisms for collecting
fees or levying charges or taxes on water users or beneficiaries, giving due consideration to
affordability to the poor; (vi) financing mechanisms: assessing the financial capabilities of each
level of the governments (central, provincial and cities/counties) for investment in basin
management and studying responsibilities in basin management of all levels of government and
basin administrative agencies; and (vii) management and institution: assessing international
best practices and exploring the possibilities for the most effective and efficient unified basin
management system and administration in the Yellow River basin.
C.  Cost Estimates and Financing Plan
4. The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,270,000 equivalent, comprising $562,000 in
foreign exchange and $708,000 equivalent in local currency. The Asian Development Bank
(ADB) will provide a grant of $970,000 from the ADB-funded TA program to cover the entire
foreign exchange cost and $408,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The Government will
contribute the balance of the local currency cost of $300,000 equivalent (Table A11).

deducted.

A.  Government Policies on Poverty Reduction
1. The People's Republic of China (PRC) National Poverty Reduction Plan (1994-2000)
designated both the loess plateau and reservoir catchment areas as two of the five typical areas
where  poverty  is  concentrated.  The  two  locations  are  characterized  by  poor  transport
infrastructure,  environmental  degradation,  slow  economic  growth,  and  low  suitability  for
agriculture and livelihood. National and provincial governments further designated official poor
counties as the target for poverty reduction activities. In 1996, the Government stressed that
poverty reduction efforts should reach the household level and adapt to local circumstances,
respect the aspirations of the poor, and promote self-help. Recent policies recognize that the
poor are found in both designated poor and non-poor counties, in rural and urban areas but with
higher concentrations in the western provinces. Because the assisted poor easily revert to
poverty because of adverse environment or economic shocks, reducing their poverty requires
comprehensive socioeconomic interventions and participatory methods.
2. For the central and eastern provinces (including the flood-prone area to benefit from the
Project), poverty reduction efforts will involve (i) identifying locally appropriate mechanisms to
address the remaining clusters of poverty, (ii) mobilizing national support and human and
financial resources in the relatively well-off areas to assist poverty reduction efforts, and  (iii)
strengthening water management infrastructure along the lower reaches of the major rivers to
prevent severe floods that contribute to major relapses into poverty.  National, provincial, and
local governments have been addressing poverty and regional disparity through a number of
measures,  including  development  of  transport  infrastructure,  prevention  of  floods  and
management of natural calamities, land improvements, and direct relief assistance. However,
budget  constraints,  limited  development  of  income-generating  opportunities,  and  lack  of
technical extension assistance and credit availability continue to hamper poverty reduction
efforts.

PRC to the Bohai Sea. The total catchment area occupies 795,000 square kilometers (km2) and
